They boast that my questions and answers are sharp and urgent.
But they really don't know the master.
They've only searched for branches and picked leaves.
They don't understand how to delve into the root.
Root-acquired branches and leaves will flourish on their own, but rootless branches and leaves can hardly survive.
Without the root, it's difficult to keep the branches and leaves.
He then tries to pretend that he's holding a spiritual pearl.
It's difficult to remove them from the self of others.
It's different from my spiritual source, Marvelous Enlightenment.
They're separated by a distance of a thousand miles.
These people are sad and ridiculous.
They say in vain that they've been training in the path for years.
Their minds are so high that they refuse to question others.
In vain, they've wasted a lifetime of uselessness and old age.
They're just foolish, confused, and dull-witted.
Their wrong views and heavy karma are the cause.
If they don't awaken in this life.
In later lifetimes, we'll fight to avoid sinking into obscurity.
Heartless Verses
"You can laugh at my mind.
It's as stubborn as it is mean.
It rises up unsteadily.
I let things settle down.
They don't understand cultivation.
Nor does it commit crimes.
They don't ever benefit others.
Nor does he do it for himself.
He doesn't observe precepts and discipline.
He doesn't honor scruples and taboos.
He doesn't know propriety or pleasure.
He doesn't practice kindness and righteousness.
It's within the power of human beings.
There's not a single meeting among them.
They come hungry for food and drink water when they're thirsty.
They come hungry for food and thirsty for water.
When he's troubled, he falls asleep.
When he's awake, he walks.
When it's hot, he puts on a single robe.
When it's cold, he covers himself with blankets.
Without thought or concern, he doesn't think.
What's sad and what's joyous?
He has no regrets and no plans.
He has no thoughts and no intentions.
The honor and disgrace of ordinary life are nothing more than a backward journey.
It's just a backwards journey.
A bird perches on a tree in the forest.
They can also be compared to them.
They can't be stopped when they come.
Nor does it stop when it leaves.
They don't avoid or seek it.
They don't praise or disparage it.
They don't tire of ugliness and evil.
He doesn't envy what's good and beautiful.
He doesn't tend to quiet rooms ...
He doesn't distance himself from the hustle and bustle of the marketplace.
He doesn't talk about what's wrong with people.
He doesn't exaggerate his own right ...
He doesn't hold himself in high esteem ...
He doesn't despise the humble.
He's kind to people who love him and hate him.
Great and small, internal and external.
They are sorrowful and joyous, and they are deprived of joy.
They respect and disparage those who are dangerous and easy.
Their minds don't see eye to eye.
He considers them honestly and single-mindedly.
Not being the first to receive good fortune, he doesn't start calamity.
It's not for the beginning of misfortune.
It's felt and then responded to.
He's compelled and then arises.
He's not afraid of sharp edges.
How can he fear tigers and bullseye?
He calls things by their proper names.
How could they be called by name?
Their eyes don't focus on form, and their voice doesn't come from their ears.
Sound doesn't come from the ear.
Whatever marks exist.
They're all false and provisional.
The physical appearance of men and women and their sounds are not definite entities.
They all lack a set body.
Their essence and characteristics are without mind.
They aren't defiled or obstructed.
He's at ease and free.
Nothing can encumber it.
The radiance of marvelous enlightenment is complete.
It reflects both surface and underneath.
It envelops the six extremes.
There's no limit to how far it goes.
What's luminous is not luminous.
It's like the moon in water.
Whether it's given or taken away is difficult.
What else can it be compared to?
He perceives this marvelous function.
It's completely beyond them.
Some people ask what they're teaching.
This is all there is.
One Hundred and Twenty-two Poems in the Month of the Western River
one
"Deluded conceptions are no longer forced to cease.
How can we really hope for the truth?
Originally, the Buddha's nature is derived from the same cultivation.
How could delusion and enlightenment be confined to past and future?
Being awakened, he becomes a buddha in a flash.
When he's deluded, he'll be reincarnated for ten thousand eons.
If he can cultivate a single thought in accord with the truth.
It will extinguish the stain of sins for an eternity.
Two.
"Inherently, there's no arising or ceasing.
It's forced to make a distinction between arising and ceasing.
It's just like sin and merit, which also have no root.
How could the marvelous essence ever be added to or subtracted from?
I have a single, bright mirror.
From the distant past, it was only obscured.
Now, it's polished and shines brightly on both heaven and earth.
It's difficult to hide the clarity of the myriad phenomena.
Three.
"My nature enters the natures of the buddhas.
That's true of the buddha-natures of all directions.
The pavilion's cold shadow shines on a cold spring.
In a single moon, a thousand pools are universally present.
It's as small as a tiny hair that's unnoticeable.
When it's large, it fills 3,000 [worlds].
Their heights aren't approximately equal, and they believe in the square and round.
It's explained as being quite short and long, deep and shallow.
Four.
"The Dharma and dharma elements are nonexistent.
Emptiness is empty, and emptiness is not empty.
Quietness, noise, speech, and silence are originally the same.
In a dream, why bother talking about a dream?
'Usefulness is uselessness in the midst of usefulness.'
Without effort, effort is exerted within effort.
If it's ripe, it'll naturally redden.
Don't ask how to cultivate the seeds.
Five.
"He forgets about good and evil for a moment.
They don't even care about prosperity and decay.
He lets obscurity and insight float and sink at will.
He follows his share of hunger, food, and thirst.
His spirit is still and perfectly tranquil.
He doesn't mind sitting and lying down, singing and chanting.
A pool of autumn water is still deep and blue.
Don't be alarmed by the wind when it stirs.
Six.
It's not necessary to forcibly extinguish the mirror in front of him.
It's called bodhi in the provisional sense.
The original form and sky, light and darkness, are originally the same.
Truth and delusion should never be separated into two essences.
Upon awakening, we'll call it the Pure Land.
There's no Tianzhu Caoqi.
Who says that paradise lies to the west of heaven?
Their realization is the appearance of Amitâbha in the world.
Seven.
"We are humans, we are sentient beings, and we live long lives.
They should rather be distinguished from one another as superior or inferior.
The Dharma body's universal illumination doesn't reach us.
We needn't search for it in each moment.
How has seeing right ever seen right?
Hearing what's not may not necessarily mean hearing what's not.
From the beginning, these things were not mutually known.
Who can obstruct you in birth-and-death?
Eight.
"He abides in the marks and cultivates generosity.
The result doesn't part from the gods and humans.
It's just like raising an arrow and shooting it at a floating cloud.
It falls only because its power is exhausted.
It's like the true mark of nonproductivity.
He returns to the source, returns to simplicity, and returns to Assuming.
He forgets his objects and emotions and lets go of the truth of heaven.
He then realizes the forbearance of the nonarising of all phenomena.
Nine.
"If the fish and rabbit were to fall back into his hands.
Naturally, he forgets about the chypnids.
The raft that crosses the river goes up the ladder to heaven.
When they reach it, they'll all be abandoned.
Before awakening, you must rely on words.
When they awaken, words become false.
Although the four phrases belong to nonproductivity, these still must be liberated.
These still need to be liberated.
Ten.
"When you awaken, you don't seek cessation.
He follows conditions and also receives the misleading masses.
He stops knowing and seeing eternalism and carries it along.
Only then does consciousness point to reality.
The five eyes, three bodies, and four kinds of cognition.
He cultivates all six perfections and ten thousand practices.
The perfect radiance is a single good maṇi.
It's both beneficial and self-helping.
Eleven.
I've seen people talk about their nature at times.
They only exaggerate their words and hasten to reward the abilities of others.
When they encounter the objective realm, they become deluded.
How are they different from foolish people?
After they've talked about it, they must then act on it.
That's how you can see that words and deeds aren't flawed.
He can chop off a mani with the sword of wisdom.
This is called the Tathāgata's correct wisdom.
Twelve.
"If he wants to understand the marvelous path of nonproduction, he must see his own true mind.
You must only see for yourself the true nature of the Buddha.
The true body has no marks and no sounds.
The pure Dharma body is nothing but nonsense.
This path is neither nonexistent nor existent.
There's nothing in it that's really sought after.
Both sides are abandoned at the center.
To see and comprehend is to be called the best quality.
